newsitem.title: FRANCE: Projected Socialist win to limit markets fall.
newsitem.headline: Projected Socialist win to limit markets fall.

text.p: A projected clear majority for the Socialist Party in Sunday's runoff parliamentary election vote was expected to mitigate falls on French financial markets, analysts and traders said.

Investors had feared a failure by the Socialists to attain an absolute majority of 289 seats in the lower house National Assembly would force them into a power-sharing deal with the Communists, who are outright opponents of the euro single currency and of social security reforms.

"It looks like the Socialists have an absolute majority so the market reaction may be rather soft," Philippe Brossard, head of research at ABN Amro Finance, said. "I would still say slightly negative but maybe not all that much."
The franc eased slightly against the mark but the fall was softened by the prospect of a Communist-free administration.
Projections from the BVA, SOFRES and CSA polling institutes early Sunday evening all showed the Socialists winning an outright majority in the National Assembly.
"I'm not expecting the franc to weaken that much. I think people had a target of 3.40 per mark if the Socialists did not have an absolute majority," Brossard said.
The franc was trading at 3.3822 per mark Sunday night compared to 3.3816 late Friday.
Prices on the Paris stock market, which fell 6 percent during the week, are expected to fall further, traders and analysts said.
Equities strategist Gary Dugan at J.P. Morgan said he expected the Paris bourse's CAC-40 index to fall next week but not more than 3 percent.
The CAC-40, which finished down 6.48 percent last week at 2,583.94 points, could fall to 2,500. "I would be surprised to see it go much lower," one analyst said.
